bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Atcheson Laughlin Hench, December 12, 1947

div1.p: Hench informs his brother that the Reed family and Kean were pleased with his recent speech at the University of Virginia, which they read about in the newspapers.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Atcheson Laughlin Hench, December 12, 1947
div1.opener:
December 12, 1947
Dr. A. L. Hench
East Jefferson Street
Charlottesville, Virginia
My dear Ach:
div1.p:
Thank you very much for the Charlottesville clippings. It is a
good thing that I said the right thing at Charlottesville, because later
when we visited General and Mrs. Reed in Washington, Mrs. Walter Reed and
Blossom in Blue Ridge Summit, and General Kean, we found that every one had
already received from friends clippings of the affair. Fortunately, they
seemed quite pleased with the clippings and gave me to understand that they
were satisfied and pleased with the way I am using their material and that
I am giving credit to whom credit is due.

Two members of the Reed family asked me for additional copies of a
Richmond paper which I did not have. They wanted to send them to other rela-
tives of the Reed family. I am not going to bother you and I hate to bother
Mr. Wranek but he will probably know what paper they refer to. The clipping
had been cut out and the name of the paper was not thereon and therefore, I
am writing to Mr. Wranek and asking for a few copies and also the name of the
paper.

Incidentally, I think a note about you to the LaFayette alumnus is
over due. You are too modest to send it in yourself, unfortunately. That
is why the alumni notes are so scarce. I would like to do it and I should
like to mention your recent election to the Ravens and that your course was
recently voted the most popular. As I am not quite sure of the significancec
of the Ravens, please help me out. I know that it is one of the highest
honors, if not the highest honor, which the University can bestow on one of
its students or faculty. Please give me an additional sentence or two which
I will send in.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
